dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Kazakhstan's government just announced they're going to study the recognition of sign language.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kazakhstan's government just announced they're going to study the recognition of sign language.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kazakhstan's government has announced plans to study the recognition of sign language, following the example of several foreign countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's a big step. They mentioned looking at international examples, right? Like the UK and Australia?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's a big step. They mentioned looking at international examples, right? Like the U K and Australia?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: International practice shows that in countries such as the United Kingdom, Iceland, Australia, New Zealand, Norway, Austria, Spain, Sweden, and South Africa, sign language is officially recognized.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. And uh, they're also planning to study manual alphabets as part of this initiative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. And uh, they're also planning to study manual alphabets as part of this initiative.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The study will also include manual alphabets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, it makes sense—they's got that sign language dictionary already, The World in Sign Language, from 2007.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, it makes sense-they's got that sign language dictionary already, The World in Sign Language, from two thousand seven.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It was noted that in 2007, the public foundation Umit " a center supporting people with hearing impairments " developed a thematic sign language dictionary for people with hearing loss in Kazakh, Russian, and English. The dictionary is called Ó˜»µ¼ Ò›¾» Ò›¸¼‹»´‹½´, which translates as The World in Sign Language.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, developed by Umit Foundation. And the manual alphabet itself has been around since 1998, used in that Alippe textbook.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, developed by Umit Foundation. And the manual alphabet itself has been around since nineteen ninety eight, used in that Alippe textbook.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Kazakh manual alphabet was first published in 1998 and used in Ó˜»–µ (Alippe) " a textbook for preparatory classes in schools for children with hearing impairments, approved by the Ministries of Education, Culture, and Healthcare.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So they've actually had some groundwork laid for a while now. It's more about formal recognition at this point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So they've actually had some groundwork laid for a while now. It's more about formal recognition at this point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it's not just education—even patrol police are getting sign language training, which is pretty cool.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it's not just education-even patrol police are getting sign language training, which is pretty cool.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Previously, the Ministry of Internal Affairs announced that patrol police officers in Kazakhstan are being trained in sign language.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's huge for accessibility. Like, making daily interactions smoother for the Deaf community.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's huge for accessibility. Like, making daily interactions smoother for the Deaf community.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. I wonder how long the study will take before they move toward actual recognition.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. I wonder how long the study will take before they move toward actual recognition.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Hopefully not too long. It sounds like they're serious about learning from other countries' models.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hopefully not too long. It sounds like they're serious about learning from other countries' models.
